byline.contributor: Eric Schmitt reported from Washington, and David D. Kirkpatrick from Cairo. Rukmini Callimachi contributed reporting from New York, and Ben Hubbard from Riyadh, Saudi Arabia.
byline.original: By ERIC SCHMITT and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

abstract: American intelligence officials warn that Islamic State is expanding far beyond its stronghold in Syria and Iraq, establishing affiliates in wide range of countries in Middle East and Africa; remains unclear whether affiliates will be effective, or merely represent opportunistic rebranding by local upstarts hoping to draft new members; trend raises fear that United States will become enmeshed in protracted, multinational conflict.
lead_paragraph: The Islamic State is expanding beyond its base in Syria and Iraq to establish militant affiliates in Afghanistan, Algeria, Egypt and Libya, raising the prospect of a new global war on terror.

headline.main: Islamic State Sprouting Limbs Beyond Its Base
headline.print_headline: Islamic State Sprouting Limbs Beyond Its Base

snippet: The Islamic State is expanding beyond its base in Syria and Iraq to establish militant affiliates in Afghanistan, Algeria, Egypt and Libya, raising the prospect of a new global war on terror.
